data-lazy-load="true" srcset="data:image/svg+xml;base64,PHN2ZyB4bWxucz0iaHR0cDovL3d3dy53My5vcmcvMjAwMC9zdmciIHZlcnNpb249IjEuMSIgaGVpZ2h0PSIyNzVweCIgd2lkdGg9IjQ5MHB4Ij48L3N2Zz4=" /> <img class="Image" alt="Barack Obama, en ese momento senador y aspirante presidencial demócrata, y el reverendo Jesse Jackson se ven en el Desayuno de Premiación de Becas del Reverendo Dr. Martin Luther King Jr., en Chicago, en 2007." srcset="https://cst.brightspotcdn.com/dims4/default/9cbd688/2147483647/strip/true/crop/1935x1086+0+471/resize/490x275!/quality/90/?url=https%3A%2F%2Fchorus-production-cst-web.s3.us-east-1.amazonaws.com%2Fbrightspot%2F8d%2Fd3%2Fb7767e324556858118df012e83a5%2Fobit-jesse-jackson.jpg 1x,https://cst.brightspotcdn.com/dims4/default/c9d8a6f/2147483647/strip/true/crop/1935x1086+0+471/resize/980x550!/quality/90/?url=https%3A%2F%2Fchorus-production-cst-web.s3.us-east-1.amazonaws.com%2Fbrightspot%2F8d%2Fd3%2Fb7767e324556858118df012e83a5%2Fobit-jesse-jackson.jpg 2x" width="490" height="275" data-src="https://cst.brightspotcdn.com/dims4/default/9cbd688/2147483647/strip/true/crop/1935x1086+0+471/resize/490x275!/quality/90/?url=https%3A%2F%2Fchorus-production-cst-web.s3.us-east-1.amazonaws.com%2Fbrightspot%2F8d%2Fd3%2Fb7767e324556858118df012e83a5%2Fobit-jesse-jackson.jpg" data-lazy-load="true" src="data:image/svg+xml;base64,PHN2ZyB4bWxucz0iaHR0cDovL3d3dy53My5vcmcvMjAwMC9zdmciIHZlcnNpb249IjEuMSIgaGVpZ2h0PSIyNzVweCIgd2lkdGg9IjQ5MHB4Ij48L3N2Zz4=" > </picture> <div class="Figure-content"><figcaption class="Figure-caption"><p>Barack Obama, en ese momento senador y aspirante presidencial demócrata, y el reverendo Jesse Jackson se ven en el Desayuno de Premiación de Becas del Reverendo Dr. Martin Luther King Jr., en Chicago, en 2007.</p></figcaption><span class="line"></span><div class="Figure-credit"><p>Charles Rex Arbogast/AP</p></div></div> </figure> </div> </div><p>Otros destacados demócratas de Illinois dijeron que la vida legendaria de Jackson impactó sus vidas, tanto personalmente como profesionalmente, incluyendo al alcalde Brandon Johnson y al fiscal general de Illinois, Kwame Raoul.</p><p>Johnson llamó a Jackson “mentor y amigo”.</p><p>“Lo honramos y su legado cosechado a pulso como luchador por la libertad, filósofo y pastor fiel de su familia y comunidad aquí en Chicago”, dijo Johnson en un comunicado. “Estoy personalmente agradecido porque el Reverendo Jackson y su familia me abrazaron a mí y a nuestra ciudad con su sabiduría y orientación. Su amistad, sus consejos y sus oraciones tuvieron un profundo impacto en mi familia”.</p><p>Raoul dijo que creció a una cuadra de la sede de Rainbow PUSH y sus palabras de “Yo soy alguien” le dieron esperanza de que él también podría ser un servidor público. “Mientras criaba a mis hijos a una cuadra de la sede de PUSH, los llevé a PUSH cuando eran pequeños para escuchar las mismas palabras”, dijo Raoul en un comunicado. “Siempre fue un sólido defensor de Haití y me retó a ser igual. Nunca dudó en retarme, sin disculparse, para mejorar mi servicio a los demás. Soy un mejor servidor público gracias al Reverendo Jesse Jackson. Descanse, reverendo; se ha ganado su paz”.</p><p>El representante Danny Davis llamó a Jackson un querido amigo y “una de las voces morales más grandes de nuestro tiempo”.</p><p>“Dedicó su vida a luchar por aquellos que habían sido excluidos y olvidados. Dio voz a los pobres, los oprimidos, los olvidados y los marginados”, dijo Davis en un comunicado. “Juntos, estuvimos al lado de los trabajadores, de los pobres, de los ancianos, de los jóvenes y de las comunidades que exigían justicia y oportunidades. Esos momentos no fueron solo protestas; fueron parte de un movimiento que ayudó a transformar vidas y expandir la justicia”.</p><p>La muerte de Jackson llega mientras su hijo <a class="Link" href="https://chicago.suntimes.com/elections/2025/10/07/jesse-jackson-jr-congressional-run-2nd-distsrict-jesse-jackson-sr-84th-birthday" target="_blank" >Jesse Jackson Jr.</a> busca un regreso político. Si Jackson Jr. gana la carrera primaria para el 2º Distrito del Congreso, Illinois estaría representado por dos Jackson en el Congreso, ya que el representante Jonathan Jackson no enfrenta oponentes en la primaria del 1er Distrito del Congreso.</p><div class="Enhancement" data-align-center> <div class="Enhancement-item" data-crop=""> <figure class="Figure"><a class="AnchorLink" id="image-aca12e" name="image-aca12e"></a> <picture data-crop="medium"> <source type="image/webp" width="490" height="275" Times</p></div></div> </figure> </div> </div><p>El gobernador JB Pritzker ordenó que las banderas ondearan a media asta en honor a Jackson. “Él rompió barreras, inspiró a generaciones y mantuvo viva la esperanza. Nuestro estado, nación y mundo son mejores gracias a sus años de servicio”, dijo Pritzker en un comunicado. Johnson también pidió que las banderas de Chicago ondearan a media asta.</p><p>La presidenta de la Junta del Condado de Cook, Toni Preckwinkle, afirmó que Jackson “abrió puertas para generaciones de líderes y cambió lo que era posible en la vida pública estadounidense”.</p><p>“Su voz nos desafió a hacer mejor y su ejemplo inspiró a muchos a entrar al servicio público en busca de equidad y oportunidad”, dijo en un comunicado.</p><p>El senador Dick Durbin dijo que él y el reverendo “no siempre estábamos de acuerdo, pero no teníamos que estar de acuerdo; nos respetábamos mutuamente”.</p><p>“Siempre tuvo como objetivo elevar a todo Estados Unidos, particularmente a aquellos de estatus minoritario. Creo que hizo una contribución real”, afirmó Durbin.</p><p>El presidente de la Cámara de Illinois, Emanuel “Chris” Welch, aseguró que Jackson “convirtió el dolor en propósito y la protesta en progreso”.</p><p>“Él se dedicó a líderes como yo, recordándonos que el servicio público consiste en levantar a quienes a menudo quedan silenciadas. Sus campañas presidenciales inspiraron a una generación a creer que nuestra política podría reflejar la plena diversidad y lo brillante de esta nación”, dijo Welch en un comunicado. “Gracias al Reverendo Jackson, millones de personas fueron registradas para votar. Gracias al Reverendo Jackson, las puertas que antes estaban cerradas fueron forzadas a abrirse. Gracias al Reverendo Jackson, tantos de nosotros estamos donde estamos hoy”.</p><p>El presidente del Senado de Illinois, Don Harmon, celebró a Jackson como “un héroe, un campeón, un agitador y un participante de primera fila en la historia”.</p><p>“Pasó su vida desafiando el status quo, luchando por los más desfavorecidos y empujando a la sociedad hacia la justicia y la igualdad. Todos somos mejores gracias a su trabajo y compromiso. Podemos honrar su legado manteniendo viva la lucha y siempre buscando un mejor mañana”, afirmó Harmon.</p><p>El expresidente Bill Clinton dijo que Jackson “defendió la dignidad humana y ayudó a crear oportunidades para que innumerables personas vivieran mejor”.</p><p>El expresidente Joe Biden dijo que “ya sea a través de palabras apasionadas en campaña o momentos de valentía silenciosa, el Reverendo Jackson influyó en generaciones de estadounidenses e incontables líderes electos, incluyendo presidentes”.</p><p>Y desde el otro lado del pasillo, el presidente Donald Trump elogió “a un buen hombre, con mucha personalidad, agallas e ‘inteligencia de calle’”, así como “una fuerza de la naturaleza como pocas antes de él”.</p><p>El concejal William Hall (6º) trabajó como coordinador de campo y asistente de viaje de Jackson durante ocho años y atesoró las tardes de domingo que a menudo pasaba en la casa del reverendo comiendo fruta.</p><p>“Viajamos a todos los continentes excepto Australia, conociendo reyes, presidentes y [la pandilla] Four Corner Hustlers. Tuve la oportunidad de ser testigo de su humanidad mientras apreciaba su corazón”, dijo Hall. “El Reverendo Jackson cambió el sistema. No estaba obsesionado con el éxito de ser elegido por el sistema. Estaba enfocado en quiénes no estaban en la mesa y por qué no obtenían lo que había en ella.”</p><p>“Me impulsa su misión y, para mi generación, recordar al reverendo es estar presente y servir como lo hacía él”.</p><p><i>Contribuyó: Matt Trunfio </i></p><p><i>Traducido con una herramienta de inteligencia artificial (AI) y editado por </i><a class="Link" href="https://chicago.suntimes.com/la-voz" target="_blank" ><i>La Voz Chicago</i></a></p>
entries.author: Tina Sfondeles

entries.title: Illinois reports first measles case of 2026
entries.summary: <p>Illinois’ first measles case of the year has been detected in the southern part of the state, state health officials said Tuesday.</p><p>People attending services at Good Shepherd Lutheran Church in Collinsville, Illinois, 15 miles east of St. Louis, on Feb. 8 between 8 a.m. and 12:15 p.m. were potentially exposed to the virus.</p><p>The state health agency emphasized that the best protection against measles is the two-dose MMR vaccine, which covers measles, mumps and rubella. The first dose is given when a child is between 12 and 15 months old, giving 93% immunity, and the second dose is given between the ages of 4 and 7, bumping immunity to 97%.</p><p>“This first reported case of measles in Illinois in 2026 is a reminder to our Illinois residents that this disease can be prevented with up-to-date vaccination,” said IDPH Director Dr. Sameer Vohra. “With almost a thousand cases in the US so far this year, the IDPH team has been preparing, working closely with local public health and health care partners on strategies to reduce spread and minimize outbreaks. … I recommend that our Illinois residents make sure that they and their family members are up to date on the MMR vaccine and all other age-appropriate immunizations.”</p><p>Symptoms can take from one to three weeks to appear after exposure to someone with measles, according to health officials, making it even more likely to spread as measles is also a highly contagious disease, according to the health agency. One person can infect up to 18 individuals. In contrast, the flu’s infection rate is about one to two people.</p><p>Because of this, anyone who isn’t vaccinated but is exposed should monitor themselves for symptoms such as rash, high fever, cough, runny nose, and red, watery eyes for 21 days, the state health agency said.</p><p>This year's first measles case comes much earlier than <a class="Link" href="https://chicago.suntimes.com/health/2025/04/24/idph-reports-first-measles-case-this-year-in-southern-illinois" target="_blank" ><u>last year’s first case</u></a>, which wasn’t detected until mid-April.</p><p>Illinois saw 14 cases in 2025 <a class="Link" href="https://chicago.suntimes.com/health/2025/07/11/illinois-measles-outbreak-over-state-health-department-officials" target="_blank" ><u>during its peak</u></a> — where nearly 1,300 cases cropped up nationwide in a short span, the worst outbreak in more than 30 years — a sharp drop from 2024’s <a class="Link" href="https://chicago.suntimes.com/health/2024/05/30/chicago-measles-outbreak-declared-over-health-department" target="_blank" ><u>three-month measles outbreak in Chicago</u></a>, where 64 cases were confirmed.</p><p>For more information about measles, contact your health care provider, or visit the Illinois Department of Public Health <a class="Link" href="https://dph.illinois.gov/topics-services/diseases-and-conditions/measles.html" target="_blank" ><u>webpage on measles</u></a> or the CDC’s <a class="Link" href="https://www.cdc.gov/measles/index.html" target="_blank" ><u>measles site</u></a>.</p>
entries.author: Sun-Times Wire

entries.title: Rev. Jesse Jackson and Chicago mayors, a tense, fraught relationship
entries.summary: <p>Rev. Jesse Jackson had a complicated, fraught and sometimes contentious relationship with Chicago mayors.</p><p>For 60 years, nine mayors had no choice but to contend with him and sometimes defer to him — even though they often didn’t like it.</p><p>They couldn’t afford not to defer to him. He was a forceful presence who knew how to organize economic and political boycotts, work the media to generate headlines and exert maximum political pressure to accomplish his civil rights goals.</p><p>A native of Greenville, S.C. Jackson moved to Chicago in 1966 to enroll at the Chicago Theological Seminary and joined the Chicago Freedom Movement, the local off-shoot of the civil rights movement led by Rev. Martin Luther King Jr.</p><p>Then-Mayor Richard J. Daley was at the zenith of his power. The civil rights movement threatened the enormous power that Daley wielded as the nation’s most powerful big city mayor and chairman of the Cook County Regular Democratic Organization — long before the Shakman decree banned political hiring and firing.</p><p>“Jesse’s whole thing was he attacked power, and nobody was a bigger representative of power at that time than the mayor,” Bill Daley, former chief of staff in Barack Obama's White House, said of his father.</p><p>“He probably thought [Jackson] was a, quote, `troublemaker,’ because he was pushing all the time for change — and most people in charge of things don’t like change.”</p><p>Fortunately for the elder Daley, there were “other ways to reach into the Black community” in those days through business, religious and political leaders, many of whom were, as Bill Daley put it, “very leery of Jackson, this young guy from South Carolina coming and and pushing them around.”</p><p>But the elder Daley still had to deal with Jackson.</p><p>“Jesse would complain about this or that and my dad would try to figure out, like he did with Martin Luther King, how to compromise, make a deal and not let things get out of hand,” Bill Daley told the Sun-Times.</p><p>Jacky Grimshaw, who served as Mayor Harold Washington’s director of intergovernmental affairs, recalled the elder Daley being “mean and disrespectful” when King arrived in Chicago and declared the city “worse than the south.”</p><p>“Jesse was pushing civil rights and supporting King on the housing crusade. Richard J. wanted control. He didn’t want to give up an inch of power,” Grimshaw recalled. “His position was, `No. I’m not doing that.’ And then, after the fight died down, he would do it… He might not do what was asked. But he would do something.”</p><h3>Jackson and Daley clash over the 1972 convention</h3><p>The biggest confrontation between Richard J. Daley and Jackson took place in 1972.</p><p>That’s when Jackson joined forces with then-Ald. Bill Singer (43rd) to unseat the Daley Democrats at the Democratic National Convention in Miami Beach — and replace them with a diverse group of delegates aligned with George McGovern. Daley was so furious about being embarrassed on the national stage, he boycotted the Miami Beach convention.</p><p>Singer said Jackson got involved in that fight belatedly, and only after the Singer-chaired Committee on Illinois Government sent a letter to Richard J. Daley informing him of the need to overhaul the Illinois delegation.</p><p>“The DNC had told us we had to have a balanced delegation of women, Hispanics and African-Americans and I just thought, what better person to be that than Jesse and, because of his prominence, I asked him to be the co-chairman,” Singer recalled. “He was an effective spokesperson for the rules of the convention… Jesse was given a prime time spot to speak at the convention, and did very effectively.”</p><p>When the Blizzard of 1979 buried Chicago and paralyzed the CTA, Daley’s successor, Michael Bilandic, made the politically fatal decision to bypass stations in Black neighborhoods.</p><p>Jackson endorsed mayoral challenger Jane Byrne.</p><p>“Byrne carried the Black community and Jesse had a major impact,” said veteran political operative Don Rose, who ran Byrne’s campaign.</p><p>Bill Daley added, “That was the spark that elected Harold Washington. No doubt about it.”</p><div class="RelatedList Enhancement" data-module data-align-center> <div class="RelatedList-title">Related</div> <ul class="RelatedList-items"> <li class="RelatedList-items-item"> <a class="Link" href="https://chicago.suntimes.com/obituaries/2026/02/17/rev-jesse-jackson-civil-rights-leader-rainbow-push-obituary" >Rev. Jesse Jackson, civil rights leader and Chicago icon, dead at 84</a> </li> </ul> </div> <p>The political alliance between Byrne and Jackson was short-lived.</p><h3>Jackson’s relationship with Byrne sours</h3><p>“She didn’t put him on the transition team and it was war from the very beginning,” Rose recalled. “She was afraid of him. She never engaged in open warfare and denunciations. But she was always hoping that some of her Black toadies would neutralize him, which they did not.”</p><p>Determined to stop then State’s Attorney Richard M. Daley from claiming the political throne, Byrne replaced Blacks with whites on boards overseeing the Chicago Public Schools and the Chicago Housing Authority. Jackson retaliated by organizing a boycott of Chicagofest and convinced Kool & the Gang to cancel their performance at the popular festival. </p><p>Harold Washington rode the wave of political outrage against Byrne and became Chicago’s first African-American mayor. Although Jackson’s Black empowerment crusade had planted the seeds for Washington’s election, there was a twinge of jealousy to their relationship, Rose and Grimshaw recalled.</p><p>“He realized that once Harold Washington was elected, he was no longer No. 1 in town… which is why he went to Washington soon after that," Rose said. “When people realized that politics was power and Jesse’s kind of leadership was inspiration, he put himself out of a job in a way. I’m sure he wished that he had been mayor. But on the other hand, he did work very hard for and was very important in Harold’s election.”</p><div class="Enhancement" data-align-center> <div class="Enhancement-item" data-crop=""> <figure class="Figure"><a class="AnchorLink" id="image-1b0000" name="image-1b0000"></a> <picture data-crop="medium"> <source type="image/webp" width="490" height="275" data-srcset="https://cst.brightspotcdn.com/dims4/default/160afab/2147483647/strip/true/crop/2068x1161+0+588/resize/490x275!/format/webp/quality/90/?url=https%3A%2F%2Fchorus-production-cst-web.s3.us-east-1.amazonaws.com%2Fbrightspot%2F63%2F05%2F87ade7ee43d8a5e8b9c767d53c4c%2Fap090611035511.jpg 1x,https://cst.brightspotcdn.com/dims4/default/051f548/2147483647/strip/true/crop/2068x1161+0+588/resize/980x550!/format/webp/quality/90/?url=https%3A%2F%2Fchorus-production-cst-web.s3.us-east-1.amazonaws.com%2Fbrightspot%2F63%2F05%2F87ade7ee43d8a5e8b9c767d53c4c%2Fap090611035511.jpg 2x" data-lazy-load="true" srcset="data:image/svg+xml;base64,PHN2ZyB4bWxucz0iaHR0cDovL3d3dy53My5vcmcvMjAwMC9zdmciIHZlcnNpb249IjEuMSIgaGVpZ2h0PSIyNzVweCIgd2lkdGg9IjQ5MHB4Ij48L3N2Zz4=" /> <source width="490" height="275" data-srcset="https://cst.brightspotcdn.com/dims4/default/d2502a9/2147483647/strip/true/crop/2068x1161+0+588/resize/490x275!/quality/90/?url=https%3A%2F%2Fchorus-production-cst-web.s3.us-east-1.amazonaws.com%2Fbrightspot%2F63%2F05%2F87ade7ee43d8a5e8b9c767d53c4c%2Fap090611035511.jpg" data-lazy-load="true" srcset="data:image/svg+xml;base64,PHN2ZyB4bWxucz0iaHR0cDovL3d3dy53My5vcmcvMjAwMC9zdmciIHZlcnNpb249IjEuMSIgaGVpZ2h0PSIyNzVweCIgd2lkdGg9IjQ5MHB4Ij48L3N2Zz4=" /> <img class="Image" alt="Rev. Jesse Jackson, head of Operation PUSH Headquarters in Chicago and then-Mayor Richard M. Daley speak during the memorial for blues singer Koko Taylor in 2009. " srcset="https://cst.brightspotcdn.com/dims4/default/d2502a9/2147483647/strip/true/crop/2068x1161+0+588/resize/490x275!/quality/90/?url=https%3A%2F%2Fchorus-production-cst-web.s3.us-east-1.amazonaws.com%2Fbrightspot%2F63%2F05%2F87ade7ee43d8a5e8b9c767d53c4c%2Fap090611035511.jpg 1x,https://cst.brightspotcdn.com/dims4/default/82e7760/2147483647/strip/true/crop/2068x1161+0+588/resize/980x550!/quality/90/?url=https%3A%2F%2Fchorus-production-cst-web.s3.us-east-1.amazonaws.com%2Fbrightspot%2F63%2F05%2F87ade7ee43d8a5e8b9c767d53c4c%2Fap090611035511.jpg 2x" width="490" height="275" data-src="https://cst.brightspotcdn.com/dims4/default/d2502a9/2147483647/strip/true/crop/2068x1161+0+588/resize/490x275!/quality/90/?url=https%3A%2F%2Fchorus-production-cst-web.s3.us-east-1.amazonaws.com%2Fbrightspot%2F63%2F05%2F87ade7ee43d8a5e8b9c767d53c4c%2Fap090611035511.jpg" data-lazy-load="true" src="data:image/svg+xml;base64,PHN2ZyB4bWxucz0iaHR0cDovL3d3dy53My5vcmcvMjAwMC9zdmciIHZlcnNpb249IjEuMSIgaGVpZ2h0PSIyNzVweCIgd2lkdGg9IjQ5MHB4Ij48L3N2Zz4=" > </picture> <div class="Figure-content"><figcaption class="Figure-caption"><p>Rev. Jesse Jackson, head of Operation PUSH Headquarters in Chicago and then-Mayor Richard M. Daley speak during the memorial for blues singer Koko Taylor in 2009. </p></figcaption><span class="line"></span><div class="Figure-credit"><p>Eric Y. Exit/AP</p></div></div> </figure> </div> </div><p>By the time Richard M. Daley began his record-setting 22-year reign, Jackson was already involved in the first of two presidential campaigns.</p><p>But that didn’t stop the civil rights icon from returning to his Chicago base on occasion to prod and pressure Richard M. Daley, just as he did with Daley's father. </p><p>“He would attack Rich on issues, on stuff he did, and not enough minority contractors," Bill Daley recalled. "He would march around City Hall on stuff, but Rich never took the bait. He never got hot.” </p><p>“Over the 22 years, they had an arms-length relationship and probably helped each other at times and, at other times, dumped on each other. But nothing dramatic.”</p><h3>Collaboration and confrontation</h3><p>Former Mayor Rahm Emanuel was a student of power who had a healthy respect for Jackson. When Emanuel closed 50 Chicago Public Schools in one fell swoop, Jackson challenged the decision both publicly and privately.</p><p>“I told him the truth. I said, `My life would be easier, Rev. Jackson, if I never did this. Those kids lives would not be.' I said parents are taking their kids out of school. They’ve decided these schools are not only shrinking in population, but failing academically. He didn’t agree with it,” Emanuel told the Sun-Times.</p><p></p><p>Jackson was also among those who led an avalanche of protests against Emanuel after the court-ordered release of the video showing Chicago police officer Jason Van Dyke shooting 17-year-old Laquan McDonald.</p><div class="RelatedList Enhancement" data-module data-align-center> <div class="RelatedList-title">Related</div> <ul class="RelatedList-items"> <li class="RelatedList-items-item"> <a class="Link" href="https://chicago.suntimes.com/politics/2026/02/17/rev-jesse-jackson-legacy-chicago-democrats" >Rev. Jesse Jackson paved the way for generations of Democrats in Chicago, top Illinois Democrats say</a> </li> </ul> </div> <p>In the furor that followed, Emanuel openly acknowledged that there was a code of silence in the Chicago Police Department. Jackson was in the City Council chambers when Emanuel “addressed it head-on.”</p><p>“There was collaboration. There was coordination. There was conflict and there was confrontation. All of it. We had a relationship. And he wouldn’t want it any other way,” Emanuel said of his relationship with Jackson.</p><p>“There were times when he thought he could rent the mayorship. And I said no. And there were other times, like what we did [with expanded minority set-asides] on the Red Line. He was an essential partner who challenged us to do better and we did.”</p><p>During a telephone interview with NBC 5 Chicago, former Mayor Lori Lightfoot recalled being somewhat intimidated by Jackson and dragging herself to a unity breakfast with County Board President Toni Preckwinkle at Operation PUSH, after she and Preckwinkle were summoned there the morning after Lightfoot’s landslide victory.</p><p>Mayor Brandon Johnson, a former paid organizer for the Chicago Teachers Union who often talks about having been arrested while protesting Emanuel’s 50 school closings in 2013, said in a statement he was “devastated to lose my mentor and friend,” adding that he was “personally grateful for Rev. Jackson and his family embracing me and our city with his wisdom and guidance.”</p><div class="Enhancement" data-align-center> <div class="Enhancement-item" data-crop=""> <figure class="Figure"><a class="AnchorLink" id="image-840000" name="image-840000"></a> <picture data-crop="medium"> <source type="image/webp" width="490" height="275" data-srcset="https://cst.brightspotcdn.com/dims4/default/4474227/2147483647/strip/true/crop/4380x2458+0+231/resize/490x275!/format/webp/quality/90/?url=https%3A%2F%2Fchorus-production-cst-web.s3.us-east-1.amazonaws.com%2Fbrightspot%2Fca%2F6a%2Fd6153817435a9aafd7339ed7640b%2Fjacksonbday-100924-18.jpg 1x,https://cst.brightspotcdn.com/dims4/default/9e47bda/2147483647/strip/true/crop/4380x2458+0+231/resize/980x550!/format/webp/quality/90/?url=https%3A%2F%2Fchorus-production-cst-web.s3.us-east-1.amazonaws.com%2Fbrightspot%2Fca%2F6a%2Fd6153817435a9aafd7339ed7640b%2Fjacksonbday-100924-18.jpg 2x" data-lazy-load="true" srcset="data:image/svg+xml;base64,PHN2ZyB4bWxucz0iaHR0cDovL3d3dy53My5vcmcvMjAwMC9zdmciIHZlcnNpb249IjEuMSIgaGVpZ2h0PSIyNzVweCIgd2lkdGg9IjQ5MHB4Ij48L3N2Zz4=" /> <source width="490" height="275" data-srcset="https://cst.brightspotcdn.com/dims4/default/a02787f/2147483647/strip/true/crop/4380x2458+0+231/resize/490x275!/quality/90/?url=https%3A%2F%2Fchorus-production-cst-web.s3.us-east-1.amazonaws.com%2Fbrightspot%2Fca%2F6a%2Fd6153817435a9aafd7339ed7640b%2Fjacksonbday-100924-18.jpg" data-lazy-load="true" srcset="data:image/svg+xml;base64,PHN2ZyB4bWxucz0iaHR0cDovL3d3dy53My5vcmcvMjAwMC9zdmciIHZlcnNpb249IjEuMSIgaGVpZ2h0PSIyNzVweCIgd2lkdGg9IjQ5MHB4Ij48L3N2Zz4=" /> <img class="Image" alt="Mayor Brandon Johnson gives Rev. Jesse Jackson a key to the city during Jackson’s 83rd birthday celebration at City Hall, Tuesday, Oct. 8, 2024. " srcset="https://cst.brightspotcdn.com/dims4/default/a02787f/2147483647/strip/true/crop/4380x2458+0+231/resize/490x275!/quality/90/?url=https%3A%2F%2Fchorus-production-cst-web.s3.us-east-1.amazonaws.com%2Fbrightspot%2Fca%2F6a%2Fd6153817435a9aafd7339ed7640b%2Fjacksonbday-100924-18.jpg 1x,https://cst.brightspotcdn.com/dims4/default/fa9a180/2147483647/strip/true/crop/4380x2458+0+231/resize/980x550!/quality/90/?url=https%3A%2F%2Fchorus-production-cst-web.s3.us-east-1.amazonaws.com%2Fbrightspot%2Fca%2F6a%2Fd6153817435a9aafd7339ed7640b%2Fjacksonbday-100924-18.jpg 2x" width="490" height="275" data-src="https://cst.brightspotcdn.com/dims4/default/a02787f/2147483647/strip/true/crop/4380x2458+0+231/resize/490x275!/quality/90/?url=https%3A%2F%2Fchorus-production-cst-web.s3.us-east-1.amazonaws.com%2Fbrightspot%2Fca%2F6a%2Fd6153817435a9aafd7339ed7640b%2Fjacksonbday-100924-18.jpg" data-lazy-load="true" src="data:image/svg+xml;base64,PHN2ZyB4bWxucz0iaHR0cDovL3d3dy53My5vcmcvMjAwMC9zdmciIHZlcnNpb249IjEuMSIgaGVpZ2h0PSIyNzVweCIgd2lkdGg9IjQ5MHB4Ij48L3N2Zz4=" > </picture> <div class="Figure-content"><figcaption class="Figure-caption"><p>Mayor Brandon Johnson gives Rev. Jesse Jackson a key to the city during Jackson’s 83rd birthday celebration at City Hall Oct. 8, 2024.</p></figcaption><span class="line"></span><div class="Figure-credit"><p>Ashlee Rezin/Sun-Times</p></div></div> </figure> </div> </div><p></p><p>Shortly after taking office, Johnson <a class="Link" href="https://chicago.suntimes.com/city-hall/2023/7/18/23799547/rainbow-push-convention-mayor-keynote-address-jesse-jackson" >delivered a keynote address </a>at the Rainbow PUSH annual convention and paid tribute to the civil rights icon.</p><p>“Throughout history, there have been exceptional individuals who rise above the ordinary [in] the perilous journey from freedom to equality. Rev. Jackson embodies that," Johnson said that day. "I am not here without the extraordinary individual who has forever impacted my life, and the world's life." </p>
entries.author: Fran Spielman

entries.title: MLBPA boss Tony Clark resigns after 'inappropriate' relationship: report
entries.summary: <p>The surprise resignation of MLB Players Association boss Tony Clark occurred after an internal investigation into an "inappropriate" relationship with his sister-in-law, who had been hired by the union in 2023, according to an ESPN report.</p><p>Clark's departure leaves the MLBPA without an executive director less than 10 months before baseball's current collective bargaining agreement expires, with a contentious labor battle expected to spill over into 2027.</p><p>Clark, a 15-year MLB veteran, became the union's executive director in 2013 after the death of previous chief Michael Weiner.</p><div class="RelatedList Enhancement" data-module data-align-center> <div class="RelatedList-title">Related</div> <ul class="RelatedList-items"> <li class="RelatedList-items-item"> <a class="Link" href="https://chicago.suntimes.com/white-sox/2026/02/17/white-sox-veterans-stress-player-unity-after-mlbpa-executive-resigns" >White Sox veterans stress player unity after MLBPA executive resigns</a> </li> <li class="RelatedList-items-item"> <a class="Link" href="https://chicago.suntimes.com/cubs/2026/02/17/cubs-react-to-tony-clark-resigning-as-mlbpa-executive-director-the-strength-of-the-union-is-in-the-players" >Cubs react to Tony Clark resigning as MLBPA executive director: ‘The strength of the union is in the players’</a> </li> </ul> </div> <p>"It's tough, obviously, the stuff that I've seen so far, but it doesn't really change the state of the union," said Detroit Tigers ace Tarik Skubal, who sits on the MLBPA's executive subcommittee. "I think we're still as strong as ever. The union has always been about the players, and it's up to us to accomplish what we want to accomplish."</p><p>The MLBPA was also under federal investigation due to its role in OneTeam Partners, a licensing company co-owned with the NFLPA and three other sports unions.</p><p><i>Read more at </i><a class="Link" href="https://www.usatoday.com" target="_blank" ><i>usatoday.com</i></a></p>
entries.author: USA TODAY

entries.title: Mix of warm temperatures, dry conditions raise risk of wind-driven fires
entries.summary: <p>The Chicago area is under a fire watch Wednesday due to unseasonably warm weather, low air moisture and gusty winds, according to the National Weather Service.</p><p>With high temps forecast in the 60s and wind gusts topping out around 40 mph, the area is under heightened fire danger, according to the NWS. The weather conditions, including low moisture in the air and a recent lack of rain and snow, also could lead to a higher risk of rapid fire spread.</p><p>The fire weather watch is in effect through Wednesday evening across much of northern Illinois, including Cook, Lake, DeKalb and DuPage counties.</p><div class="Enhancement" data-align-center><div class="Enhancement-item"> <div class="ExternalContent-wrapper" > <div class="TweetUrl"> <blockquote class="twitter-tweet"><p lang="en" dir="ltr">The combination of warm temperatures, dry conditions, and strong westerly winds will lead to an increased threat for fire spread tomorrow especially along and north of Interstate 88. Limit activities that may cause sparks or involve open flames. <a href="https://twitter.com/hashtag/ILwx?src=hash&ref_src=twsrc%5Etfw">#ILwx</a> <a href="https://twitter.com/hashtag/INwx?src=hash&ref_src=twsrc%5Etfw">#INwx</a> <a href="https://t.co/yGkzr1HvrJ">pic.twitter.com/yGkzr1HvrJ</a></p>— NWS Chicago (@NWSChicago) <a href="https://twitter.com/NWSChicago/status/2023866207443513784?ref_src=twsrc%5Etfw">February 17, 2026</a></blockquote> <script async src="https://platform.twitter.com/widgets.js" charset="utf-8"></script> </div> </div> </div></div><p>The NWS recommends against burning yard waste because of the likelihood for fires to spread.</p><p>“It’s getting warmer here, I’m sure a lot of people will be tempted to burn yard waste,” said NWS meteorologist Kevin Doom. “Maybe avoid that, but if you do just keep an extra eye on it … it can be really easy for a spark to run loose and ignite something else.”</p><p>Fire weather hazards are most common in the fall and spring, though they can happen any time of year, Doom said. He also cautioned people to use extra care when disposing of burning materials like cigarette butts.</p><p>Chicago set a record-high <a class="Link" href="https://chicago.suntimes.com/weather/2026/02/16/chicago-forecast-warm-weather-record-high-temperature-monday" target="_blank" ><u>temperature</u></a> Monday as the city recorded a 65-degree day.</p>
entries.author: Mary Norkol

entries.title: Registered sex offender accused of raping woman in Humboldt Park alley
entries.summary: <p>A man suspected of raping a woman in a Humboldt Park alley in January was ordered detained.</p><p>Arthur White, a 40-year-old registered sex offender, faces a felony count of aggravated criminal sexual assault. He allegedly followed a woman down Lawndale Avenue on Jan.12 and asked if she needed his help, prosecutors said.</p><p>When she declined his offer, White walked ahead of the woman, then ducked into a viaduct. When she passed the viaduct, police say he grabbed her and pushed her into an alley in the 1400 block of North Lawndale Avenue. The woman screamed for help as he shoved her into garbage cans and removed his belt, prosecutors said.</p><p>The woman tried to escape, but White held her down and struck her in the head, prosecutors said. He dragged her by her sweater and pulled down her pants. He then pulled down his pants and sexually assaulted her.</p><p>The woman screamed, but White covered her mouth and she struggled to breathe, prosecutors said. White left the scene after the alleged assault.</p><p>The woman called 911 and was taken to Mount Sinai Hospital, where she was treated and hospital staff collected evidence for a rape kit. Police spoke to business owners near the scene and gathered surveillance video that corroborated the woman’s account.</p><p>A week after the alleged assault, prosecutors say White approached a woman at a nearby Subway restaurant and pestered her. When she didn’t respond, he grabbed her buttocks and she drew a pocketknife and told him not to grab her again. White was arrested, and the woman in the sex assault case identified him as the man who raped her, prosecutors said.</p><p>White is a registered sex offender who raped his 5-year-old sister when he was 15.</p><p>At a court hearing this week, White was ordered detained until his next court date Feb. 24.<br></p>
entries.author: Mary Norkol

entries.title: Bears will raise season ticket prices 13.5%
entries.summary: <p>The <a class="Link" href="https://chicago.suntimes.com/bears" target="_blank" >Bears</a>’ playoff run came at a cost.</p><p>The team is raising the price of season tickets by an average of 13.5% in 2026, president/CEO Kevin Warren said in a letter to season ticket-holders Tuesday. He cited “detailed analysis and market research” as his reasoning.</p><p>The <a class="Link" href="https://chicago.suntimes.com/bears/2026/02/14/one-columnists-look-at-what-the-future-holds" target="_blank" >Bears</a> are in the process of looking for a home for a new stadium, be it Arlington Heights or in Northwest Indiana. Movement on either front could happen this month.</p><p>A jump in price was expected this year. The Bears, after all, raised ticket prices 10% last year despite coming off a 5-12 record and the first-ever in-season firing of their head coach. In 2024, Warren announced an 8% average increase in season ticket prices in the wake of a 7-10 season.</p><p>Warren said that the Bears will play a first-place schedule in 2026 but “have the best home-field advantage in the NFL.” The Bears will host nine regular season games, up one from last year, and one preseason game, down one from 2025. Since switching to a 17-game schedule, the NFL has rotated the extra home game by conference.</p><bsp-list-loadmore class="PageListH" data-module data-hide-authors="true" data-hide-categories="true" entries.title: DePaul y Loyola acusadas de orillar a familias de bajos ingresos a préstamos altos y de favorecer a ricos
entries.summary: <p>Dos universidades de Chicago están entre unas docenas de escuelas en todo el país que parecen favorecer a las familias con mayores recursos al ofrecer paquetes de ayuda financiera, según un nuevo reporte.</p><p>La Universidad Loyola de Chicago y la Universidad DePaul fueron nombradas en un <a class="Link" href="https://www.newamerica.org/education-policy/reports/parent-plus-subprime-loans-universities-debt/" target="_blank" >reporte publicado el jueves por el grupo de reflexión progresista New America</a>, que alega que se encuentran entre 41 escuelas universitarias a nivel nacional que presionan a una gran parte de las familias de bajos ingresos a solicitar préstamos elevados para cubrir los costos universitarios, mientras ofrecen atractivas becas a familias más ricas con estudiantes de alto rendimiento.</p><p>Las escuelas mencionadas en el reporte tienen un alto porcentaje de familias de bajos ingresos que solicitan préstamos que a menudo no pueden pagar, según el autor Steven Burd, escritor principal y editor del programa de política educativa de New America. La cantidad que los padres piden en préstamos es a veces mayor que sus ingresos anuales, encontró el reporte.</p><div class="RichTextSidebarModule Enhancement" data-module data-align-center><a class="AnchorLink" id="module-300000" name="module-300000"></a> <div class="RichTextModule-items RichTextBody"><h3>La Voz Chicago WhatsApp</h3>Encuentra más noticias en nuestro canal de WhatsApp. <a class="Link" href="https://www.whatsapp.com/channel/0029Vb0XT1XCHDylm3rCs40P" target="_blank" ><b>Síguenos.</b></a></div> </div><p>“Lo que realmente preocupa es que están metiendo a estas familias en problemas financieros reales, en una verdadera vulnerabilidad financiera”, dijo Burd.</p><p>El reporte se centra en los préstamos federales Parent PLUS, que los padres pueden utilizar para pagar costos de matrícula que no pueden cubrir con sus propios recursos o a través de becas.</p><p>Mientras que la mayoría de los préstamos estudiantiles federales tienen límites, las familias pueden solicitar préstamos Parent PLUS por un monto que cubra el costo total de la asistencia. Pero los préstamos Parent PLUS, que tienen una tasa de interés fija alta y tarifas de origen, no fueron diseñados para familias de bajos ingresos, dijo Burd. Estaban destinados a ayudar a familias de ingresos medios y altos a enviar a sus hijos a escuelas más prestigiosas y costosas, agregó.</p><p>“Nunca se pensaron como una manera para que las escuelas pudieran ayudar a estudiantes de bajos ingresos”, afirmó Burd.</p><p>Los funcionarios de DePaul dicen que la universidad proporciona becas y subvenciones y ofrece información sobre diversos préstamos, pero, ultimadamente, las familias deciden cuánto pedir prestado. Un portavoz de la Universidad Loyola dijo que la universidad “trabaja proactivamente con estudiantes y familias para presentar todas las opciones disponibles”, sin dirigir a las familias hacia ninguna opción en particular.</p><p>“Loyola seguirá fortaleciendo los recursos que ayudan a las familias a manejar los costos educativos y minimizar la deuda”, dijo el portavoz en un comunicado.</p><p>Con los préstamos Parent PLUS, las escuelas no son responsables si los prestatarios caen en default, y se espera que la administración de Trump comience pronto a embargar salarios de personas que no han cumplido sus préstamos estudiantiles después de una pausa en los pagos que comenzó durante la pandemia de COVID-19.</p><p>Las escuelas pueden ofrecer a los estudiantes becas basadas en el mérito, según sus calificaciones y éxito académico, incluso si no califican para asistencia basada en la necesidad. Y esas becas pueden acabar ocupando una gran parte de los fondos de ayuda financiera de una escuela, dejando a los estudiantes de bajos ingresos en necesidad de préstamos; ahí es donde entran los préstamos Parent PLUS, agregó Burd.</p><p>El problema se agrava, explicó Burd, cuando las escuelas ofrecen mejores paquetes de ayuda financiera a estudiantes cuyas familias ganan más, una estrategia que, dice, a menudo está destinada a atraer a estudiantes de alto rendimiento y con recursos que podrían hacer donaciones generosas en el futuro. Eso incentiva a las universidades a reclutar estudiantes con la mirada puesta en “generar ingresos para su institución y subir en las clasificaciones”, dijo Burd.</p><p>Algunas escuelas han utilizado esta práctica para mejorar su posición en las clasificaciones nacionales, conocidas en inglés como “rankings”, y transformarse de una humilde escuela que atrae estudiantes locales a una universidad competitiva a nivel nacional, dice el reporte.</p><p>Para encontrar escuelas que parecían estar dirigiendo a las familias de bajos ingresos a préstamos Parent PLUS, Burd buscó colleges donde una gran parte de los estudiantes que recibían becas Pell, destinadas a estudiantes de bajos ingresos, tenían padres que solicitaban préstamos Parent PLUS.</p><p>En la Universidad DePaul, el 53% de los estudiantes cuyos padres solicitaron préstamos Parent PLUS eran beneficiarios de becas Pell y sus padres pidieron prestado un promedio de $33,000 en préstamos PLUS, según el reporte.</p><p>En Loyola, el 48% de los estudiantes cuyos padres tenían préstamos Parent PLUS contaba con becas Pell. La deuda promedio de los préstamos Parent PLUS asumida por esos padres de Loyola era de aproximadamente $46,000.</p><div class="Enhancement" data-align-center> <div class="Enhancement-item" data-src="https://cst.brightspotcdn.com/dims4/default/3c844ab/2147483647/strip/true/crop/6720x3771+0+354/resize/490x275!/quality/90/?url=https%3A%2F%2Fchorus-production-cst-web.s3.us-east-1.amazonaws.com%2Fbrightspot%2F80%2F68%2F198a9100482b85e1b0223019dd32%2Floyola-03312020-empty-university-campus-mm00001.jpg" data-lazy-load="true" src="data:image/svg+xml;base64,PHN2ZyB4bWxucz0iaHR0cDovL3d3dy53My5vcmcvMjAwMC9zdmciIHZlcnNpb249IjEuMSIgaGVpZ2h0PSIyNzVweCIgd2lkdGg9IjQ5MHB4Ij48L3N2Zz4=" > </picture> <div class="Figure-content"><figcaption class="Figure-caption"><p>En la Universidad Loyola de Chicago, el 48% de los estudiantes cuyos padres tienen préstamos Parent PLUS recibió becas Pell para estudiantes de bajos ingresos. Su carga promedio de deuda es de aproximadamente $46,000.</p></figcaption><span class="line"></span><div class="Figure-credit"><p>Manuel Martinez/Archivo WBEZ</p></div></div> </figure> </div> </div><p>“Estas son familias que ganan $30,000 o menos, y luego están asumiendo $30,000 en deuda para que sus hijos puedan estudiar”, dijo Burd. “Estas escuelas están cobrando tanto, que están dejando una brecha de ayuda financiera tan grande que las familias no tienen otra opción que solicitar estos préstamos PLUS”.</p><p>Un portavoz de la Universidad DePaul dijo que la escuela trabaja para aliviar la carga financiera sobre los estudiantes, pero no abordó directamente preguntas sobre las familias de bajos ingresos que solicitan préstamos Parent PLUS o cómo la escuela decide qué ayuda ofrecer a los estudiantes más ricos. El portavoz dijo que DePaul proporciona a los estudiantes más de $350 millones al año en becas académicas y subvenciones basadas en la necesidad usando fondos institucionales y donaciones filantrópicas.</p><p>“DePaul ofrece información a estudiantes y familias respecto a diversas opciones de préstamos, y ultimadamente, las familias toman la decisión de proceder con los préstamos como lo consideren adecuado”, escribió el portavoz en un comunicado.</p><p>Los 41 colegios y universidades privados y públicos mencionados en el reporte gastaron en conjunto $2.4 mil millones de su dinero de ayuda financiera en estudiantes que no necesitaban la ayuda en 2023, según los datos más recientes disponibles.</p><p>Casi $2 de cada $5 gastados en ayuda financiera fueron destinados a estudiantes que el gobierno federal considera capaces de pagar la universidad sin ayuda adicional, encontró el reporte.</p><p>Burd comenzó con una lista de más de 300 colegios y universidades selectivas con un cierto tamaño de fondo, excluyendo colegios históricamente negros porque, según dijo, han sido históricamente subfinanciados y tienen muy poca ayuda financiera para ofrecer. Las escuelas de arte también fueron excluidas porque están entre las más caras, en parte debido a los costosos suministros y herramientas.</p><p>Burd luego buscó escuelas donde las familias de los beneficiarios de becas Pell representaban al menos un tercio de los prestatarios de préstamos PLUS y el monto promedio de los préstamos era al menos de $15,000. En las 41 escuelas mencionadas en el reporte, el 45% de los prestatarios eran padres de beneficiarios de Pell, y solicitaron un monto promedio de $29,102.</p><p>Algunos legisladores han notado esta tendencia y han establecido un límite a los préstamos Parent PLUS de $65,000 por hijo, pero Burd dice que eso sigue siendo demasiado para muchas familias pedir prestado. Dijo que idealmente se implementará una legislación para detener a las escuelas de dirigir a las familias hacia préstamos que no pueden pagar.</p><p>“Sin embargo, la única otra preocupación es que los prestamistas privados entren y comiencen a ofrecer productos aún más depredadores”, dijo. “Así que eso también debemos vigilarlo”.</p><p><i>Traducido con una herramienta de inteligencia artificial (AI) y editado por </i><a class="Link" href="https://chicago.suntimes.com/la-voz" target="_blank" ><i>La Voz Chicago</i></a></p>
entries.author: Mary Norkol

entries.title: Man's death at Naval Station Great Lakes is under investigation
entries.summary: <p>The death of a Florida man at Naval Station Great Lakes is under investigation after he was found unresponsive in the barracks Sunday, according to the Lake County coroner’s office.</p><p>Navy Region Mid-Atlantic Fire and Emergency Services and the Great Lakes Police Department responded about 12:15 p.m. to a medical call in the barracks of the base and found Joshua Jones, 19, unresponsive, the office said in a statement. He was pronounced dead at the scene.</p><p>Coroner's officials confirmed Jones was stationed at the base. Naval Station Great Lakes didn't immediately respond to a request for comment.</p><p>An autopsy was conducted, a cause or manner of death has not yet been released. The Lake County coroner's office said autopsy results were pending the completion of an expanded toxicology test.</p><p>The Naval Criminal Investigative Service is investigating.</p>
entries.author: Sun-Times Wire

entries.title: New White Sox assistant GM sees high upside in youthful team
entries.summary: <p>GLENDALE, Ariz. — The word ‘‘momentum’’ has been used frequently at the <a class="Link" href="https://chicago.suntimes.com/white-sox" target="_blank" >White Sox</a>’ spring-training camp.</p><p>It’s why new assistant general manager Carlos Rodriguez chose to join the Sox in December after spending 16 seasons in the Rays’ organization.</p><p>‘‘I had a bunch of conversations with [GM] Chris [Getz] over time,’’ Rodriguez said of the lead-up to his hiring, which <a class="Link" href="https://chicago.suntimes.com/white-sox/2025/12/19/white-sox-hire-carlos-rodriguez-as-assistant-general-manager" target="_blank" ><u>the Sox announced</u></a> Dec. 19. ‘‘Just felt we are really aligned — aligned on his vision for the organization, the people, the process in place. Kind of got caught up in just thinking about the possibilities, the upside.’’</p><p>As an outsider looking in, Rodriguez saw the Sox’ abysmal last few years — three consecutive seasons of 100-plus losses in 2023-25 — as a fresh start for them to build up their player-development system.</p><p>Many trades and a couple of seemingly productive drafts later, the Sox might be trending in the right direction. They are one of seven major-league teams with five players listed among <a class="Link" href="https://www.mlb.com/milb/prospects/top100/" target="_blank" ><u>MLB.com’s</u></a> top 100 prospects.</p><p>Rodriguez spent the last six seasons as the Rays’ vice president/assistant GM. Before that, he oversaw the strapped-for-cash team’s player-development and international-scouting department.</p><p>The Rays were contenders for part of his time with them, making eight playoff appearances and one World Series appearance (2020) and hovering around .500 the other years.</p><p>Perhaps the Sox brought him in in an effort to emulate the Rays’ blueprint for success: winning without doling out too much cash and without signing players to long-term deals.</p><p>The Sox have had similarly small payrolls but haven’t found the same kind of success. For example, in 2018, the Sox’ and Rays’ payrolls were both around $75 million, but the Rays finished 90-72, while the Sox, who were going through a rebuild at the time, went 62-100.</p><p>‘‘I just think it was a very collaborative process,’’ Rodriguez said of what worked well with the Rays. ‘‘And just the relentless pursuit of trying to find different ways to get better.</p><p>‘‘We were a higher-transaction team, but it does require the old cliché: great scouting, great player development and the ability to get the most out of those players. Whenever you are transacting, making sure that you nail some of those traits.’’</p><p>Under Getz’s tenure, the Sox have shown some similarities to the Rays by making many low-risk, high-reward acquisitions. But several big trades also have helped to replenish their farm system, mainly the Garrett Crochet deal with the Red Sox that brought in second baseman Chase Meidroth, catcher Kyle Teel, outfield prospect Braden Montgomery and reliever Wikelman Gonzalez.</p><div class="Enhancement" data-align-center> <div class="Enhancement-item" data-crop=""> <figure class="Figure"><a class="AnchorLink" prospects were selected in the last two years) and eventually build up their international system. That carries on this year with their No. 1 overall pick, which is projected to be UCLA shortstop Roch Cholowsky.</p><p>Nine players made their MLB debuts with the Sox in 2025, with most of them showing some promise to stick in the big leagues.</p><p></p><p>‘‘I just feel like the younger guys on the team, you get to see the confidence that they have going into this year,’’ Teel said. ‘‘You can see how we’re rolling on from last year. I feel like we’re continuing that momentum, and it’s a really great thing to see.’’</p><p></p><p>The Sox’ heightened expectations were amplified when they added Japanese slugger Munetaka Murakami and bolstered the back of their bullpen by signing closer Seranthony Dominguez.</p><p></p><p>‘‘Coming into this year, they know what it’s like to be in the big leagues,’’ veteran outfielder/designated hitter Andrew Benintendi said. ‘‘Obviously, your confidence will go up. And there’s a lot of great players in here, the guys who were here last year and some new faces that are going to help us a lot. Definitely an exciting time.’’</p><div class="PageListL" data-module data-hide-authors="true" data-hide-categories="true" data-hide-dates="true" data-show-loadmore="true" ><a class="AnchorLink" id="list-4a0005" name="list-4a0005"></a><div class="PageList-header" > <div class="PageList-header-title-wrap" > <div class="PageList-header-title"> <a class="" href="https://chicago.suntimes.com/white-sox" target="{borderColor=#dfdfdf, pageNumber=1, inverseColors=false, items=[{category=[{items=[White Sox]}], type=Image, description=[{items=[Tony Clark, the MLBPA executive director, stepped down Tuesday after 13 years in the role. entries.author: Kade Heather

entries.title: White Sox veterans stress player unity after MLBPA executive resigns
entries.summary: <p>GLENDALE, Ariz. — <a class="Link" href="https://chicago.suntimes.com/white-sox" >White Sox</a> veterans emphasized togetherness for players around the league in wake of the surprising news Tuesday morning that MLB Players Association Executive Director <b>Tony Clark</b> is resigning.</p><p>Clark, who held the role since 2013, steps down as the players association is expected in the coming months to begin collective bargaining with the MLB for a new labor deal as the current contract expires Dec. 1.</p><p>The league could be headed toward a lockout to start the 2027 season, with league executives seemingly pushing to impose a salary cap, which players have historically opposed.</p><p><b>Andrew Benintendi</b>, the team’s most veteran player with 10 seasons under his belt, said the talk of a potential lockout has only brought players closer together. The goal is always to prioritize the players’ needs, even if that means sacrificing some games next season, he said.</p><div class="RelatedList Enhancement" data-module data-align-center> <div class="RelatedList-title">Related</div> <ul class="RelatedList-items"> <li class="RelatedList-items-item"> <a class="Link" href="https://chicago.suntimes.com/cubs/2026/02/17/cubs-react-to-tony-clark-resigning-as-mlbpa-executive-director-the-strength-of-the-union-is-in-the-players" >Cubs react to Tony Clark resigning as MLBPA executive director: ‘The strength of the union is in the players’</a> </li> <li class="RelatedList-items-item"> <a class="Link" href="https://chicago.suntimes.com/mlb/2026/02/17/mlbpa-boss-tony-clark-resigns" >MLBPA boss Tony Clark resigns after ‘inappropriate’ relationship: report</a> </li> </ul> </div> <p>“Obviously, I think we want to be out on the field. There’s a lot of things we can’t control,” Benintendi, 31, said. “Going forward, we’re always going to be together. Talks will happen and we’re going to put players first and we want to be out there, we don’t want to miss games. But if that’s what needs to happen, we’re going to be together and we’ll go from there.”</p><p>Added Benintendi: “What’s important is that I think all the players are in unison as we always have been. We’ll be in discussions in the next day or two. We’ll leave it at this.”</p><div class="Enhancement" data-align-center> <div class="Enhancement-item" data-crop=""> <figure class="Figure"><a class="AnchorLink" id="image-0a0000" data-lazy-load="true" src="data:image/svg+xml;base64,PHN2ZyB4bWxucz0iaHR0cDovL3d3dy53My5vcmcvMjAwMC9zdmciIHZlcnNpb249IjEuMSIgaGVpZ2h0PSIyNzVweCIgd2lkdGg9IjQ5MHB4Ij48L3N2Zz4=" > </picture> <div class="Figure-content"><figcaption class="Figure-caption"><p>Tony Clark has resigned as executive director of the Major League Baseball Players Association.</p></figcaption><span class="line"></span><div class="Figure-credit"><p>Richard Drew/AP</p></div></div> </figure> </div> </div><p><b>Davis Martin</b>, the Sox’s longest tenured player by service time, said player representatives planned to meet with the union Tuesday and speak about next steps.</p><p>He and other veterans on the team expressed pride in the brotherhood-like spirit of the MLBPA.</p><p>“You're talking guys who have played together, guys who have played against each other for years all the way through the minor leagues, all the way through the major leagues,” Martin, 29, said. “You get to play with guys and those relationships never change. I can call <b>Garrett Crochet</b> right now and we can have a conversation with him.”</p><p>“Unity across the board is our strength, it's always been our strength and baseball players in a nutshell are always cut from similar cloth regardless of country, origin, in general. That's our perspective,” he added.</p><p>Following Clark’s announcement, the MLBPA canceled the start of its yearly spring training tour of all 30 clubs Tuesday, which was set to begin with the Cleveland Guardians and the Sox.</p><p>The resignation also comes amid a federal investigation into the MLBPA's finances related to a youth baseball company.</p><h3><b>High praise for Chase, Braden</b></h3><p>White Sox manager <b>Will Venable</b> raved about second baseman <b>Chase Meidroth</b> and outfielder <b>Braden Montgomery</b> — both acquired in the Crochet trade — as two guys who “did an outstanding job and added a ton of jumps in a lot of different metrics” during the offseason.</p><p>Venable said Montgomery’s maturity stands out for a 22 year old.</p><p>“He has a very thoughtful plan. Everything he does is with a purpose,” Venable said. “Not surprising that after a healthy offseason he’s able to turn his body into even more of a weapon than it was before. He’s an extremely physical guy that has put on good weight and looks great out there.”</p><p>Meidroth, who played a bulk of last season as the Sox’ leadoff hitter, appears “more flexible and mobile” this spring, the second-year manager said.</p><p>“He looks great running, it looks like he’s faster. … Credit to him,” Venable said.</p><p></p><div class="PageListL" data-module data-hide-authors="true" data-hide-categories="true" data-hide-dates="true" data-show-loadmore="true" ><a class="AnchorLink" id="list-4a0005" name="list-4a0005"></a><div class="PageList-header" > <div class="PageList-header-title-wrap" > <div class="PageList-header-title"> <a class="" href="https://chicago.suntimes.com/white-sox" target="{borderColor=#dfdfdf, pageNumber=1, inverseColors=false, footerBgColor=#000000, bodyFont=font-3, showListNumbers=false, imagePositionHorizontal=null, rteBodyFont=font-3, headerBottomBorderColor=#111010, subTitle=null, stickyHeader=true, listTitleColor=#000000, tableCellBorderColor=#ccd1d5, pageCount=2425, relatedListFont=font-1, hideAuthors=true, tertiaryTextColor=#6c6c6c, buttonHoverTextColor=#ffffff, tableFont=font-1, pagination=[{body=[Next Page], href=?p=2, _template=/link/Link.hbs, contentId=null, pianoSectionSlug=null, target=null}], carouselAutoPlay=false, items=[{category=[{items=[White Sox]}], type=Image, _styledTemplate=null, title=White Sox veterans stress player unity after MLBPA executive resigns, imageAlignment=null, categoryUrl=https://chicago.suntimes.com/white-sox, description=[{items=[Tony Clark, the MLBPA executive director, stepped down Tuesday after 13 years in the role.
